title: Failed airlines will now be forced to fly tourists home
text:
Airlines which go bust in future will have their planes seized by the Government and used to bring home holidaymakers under new laws designed to save taxpayers millions.

The collapse of Thomas Cook last month triggered a £100million operation by the Civil Aviation Authority to repatriate almost 150,000 stranded tourists on a fleet of 62 chartered jets.

However, the expense raised questions over why it was unable to use Thomas Cook's crew and fleet of planes.

Airlines which go bust in future will have their planes seized by the Government and used to bring home holidaymakers under new laws designed to save taxpayers millions. Pictured: Thomas Cook collapsed into bankruptcy on September 23

Ministers were accused of failing to learn from the 2017 collapse of Monarch Airlines.

A review had called for reform to allow insolvent airlines to continue flying for a short time to bring passengers home.

But Government claimed it had not had time to change the law by the time Thomas Cook went under.

The collapse of Thomas Cook last month triggered a £100million operation by the Civil Aviation Authority to repatriate almost 150,000 stranded tourists on a fleet of 62 chartered jets. Pictured: British tourists boarding a plane to come home from Mugla, Turkey

Now Transport Secretary Grant Shapps is vowing to bring in reforms 'as quickly as possible'.

He said: 'I'm determined to bring in a better system to deal with similar situations in future.'

A Department for Transport spokesman added: 'Using existing assets and staff in order to get people home will help to cut the costs of repatriation.'
